unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Logistics Delays Plague Festive Season Prep**
normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Logistics Delays Plague Festive Season Prep**

unnormalised: Mumbai, Oct 26 – Indian manufacturers are facing significant logistics delays, threatening timely delivery of goods ahead of Diwali. A surge in demand coupled with existing infrastructure bottlenecks is creating a perfect storm, reminiscent of the “Bhagam Bhag” chaos on the roads.
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty six – Indian manufacturers are facing significant logistics delays, threatening timely delivery of goods ahead of Diwali. A surge in demand coupled with existing infrastructure bottlenecks is creating a perfect storm, reminiscent of the “Bhagam Bhag” chaos on the roads.

unnormalised: Trucking companies report delays of up to 72 hours on key routes like the Delhi-Mumbai corridor, impacting everything from consumer electronics to textiles sourced from Surat. The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has flagged concerns over rising transportation costs, with some routes seeing a 20% hike in rates.
normalised: Trucking companies report delays of up to seventy two hours on key routes like the Delhi-Mumbai corridor, impacting everything from consumer electronics to textiles sourced from Surat. The C I I has flagged concerns over rising transportation costs, with some routes seeing a twenty percent hike in rates.

unnormalised: "The delays are crippling," says Rajesh Sharma, owner of a garment manufacturing unit in Tiruppur. "We're struggling to get our festive stock to retailers on time. We are already facing a loss of almost Rs. 5 Lakhs."
normalised: "The delays are crippling," says Rajesh Sharma, owner of a garment manufacturing unit in Tiruppur. "We're struggling to get our festive stock to retailers on time. We are already facing a loss of almost rupee five lakhs."

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Logistics is reportedly studying the bottlenecks and proposing solutions, including optimizing warehouse locations and improving last-mile connectivity. Experts suggest leveraging rail freight more effectively could alleviate some pressure on road transport, especially for distances exceeding 500 km. The situation is expected to persist through November.
normalised: The Indian Institute of Logistics is reportedly studying the bottlenecks and proposing solutions, including optimizing warehouse locations and improving last-mile connectivity. Experts suggest leveraging rail freight more effectively could alleviate some pressure on road transport, especially for distances exceeding five hundred kilometer. The situation is expected to persist through November.
